content.rendered:
AEC Tech NYC 11/11 – 11/16/2025


AEC Tech NYC 2025 brought together designers, engineers, and technologists to look closely at how technology is actually being used in practice today. Rather than centering on tools in isolation, the conference focused on workflows, decision-making, and collaboration across firms. Perkins&Will participated in several parts of the conference, including the Tech Crawl, Symposium, and Hackathon.

As part of the Tech Crawl, Perkins&Will hosted one of the open-studio visits at the New York office. The session was informal and discussion-driven, offering visitors a view into how digital tools and processes are developed and tested within live project conditions. The focus was less on finished solutions and more on how teams work through complexity, adapt standards, and balance experimentation with delivery.

The Symposium formed the core discussion event of the conference, with Perkins&Will hosting one of the sessions in its New York studio. Talks and panels covered a range of topics, including computational design, data-driven workflows, environmental analysis, and the growing role of automation in design and engineering. Much of the conversation centered on how these technologies are changing the structure of practice—how decisions are made, how responsibilities shift, and how designers maintain authorship and accountability as systems become more complex.

The conference concluded with a two-day Hackathon that emphasized making over presentation. Interdisciplinary teams formed quickly and worked intensively to prototype tools and workflows responding to real challenges in the AEC industry. Perkins&Will team members participated alongside peers from other firms, contributing design insight and technical experience while testing ideas through rapid iteration.

Taken together, these moments reflected a shared interest in openness, practical experimentation, and learning through doing. Perkins&Will’s involvement across the conference reinforced the value of engaging directly with evolving technologies—not as finished products, but as part of an ongoing, collective practice.

Updated SharePoint Link Permission Guidance

SharePoint Sharing: Default to People You Choose (External Sharing)

When sharing files externally in SharePoint, the default mindset should be intentional access. In nearly all cases, “People you Choose” should be your go-to option for external sharing—ensuring the right external partners have the right level of access while keeping our documents secure and compliant.

Sharing settings can be adjusted by clicking the gear icon in the Share screen. Taking a moment here helps prevent access issues, protects sensitive information, and keeps collaboration predictable—especially when working with consultants, clients, and vendors.

Internal sharing guidance remains unchanged:
For internal collaboration, continue to prioritize “People in Perkins&Will” to provide seamless access for colleagues while maintaining firmwide security standards.

Note: Some Clients/Projects have “need to know” requirements in our contracts.  This means that use of the “People in Perkins&Will” link cannot be used due to the lack of our ability to audit who has accessed the information. Please verify with your Project Manager and/or CEL if your project has this type of restriction.

SharePoint Link Usage Policy (External Sharing)

1. Default: Controlled External Collaboration

For documents or folders that require editing, commenting, or ongoing collaboration with external partners, always use “This link works for… People you Choose.”

  • Access is granted only to named individuals by entering their email addresses.
  • Permissions are clear, auditable, and aligned with our security standards.
  • Recipients will be required to sign in with Microsoft to verify they are the intended receiver.
  • This is the only approved method for granting edit or collaboration rights to external users.

Using “People you Choose” ensures accountability, minimizes risk, and avoids accidental oversharing—particularly for active project work and contractual deliverables.

Note: Once you have shared a folder with someone using “People you Choose”, you can send them links to individual files and subfolders by picking “People with Existing Access”. 

2. Exception: View-Only External Dissemination

In limited situations, external recipients may have trouble accessing files due to client IT policies, security incompatibilities, or contractual constraints.
If this occurs, pause and confirm with the Project Manager before proceeding.

Once confirmed, a view-only “This link works for… Anyone” link may be used for external dissemination only.

  • “Anyone” links are view-only and cannot be used for collaboration.
  • Links automatically expire after 30 days.
  • For sensitive or confidential content, apply a password before sharing.

This option should be treated as a fallback, not a default.

Note: Some Clients/Projects have “need to know” requirements in our contracts.  This means that use of the ‘Anyone‘ link cannot be used due to the lack of our ability to audit who has accessed the information. Please verify with your Project Manager and/or CEL if your project has this type of restriction.


Sample of the additional share settings accessed by clicking the gear icon

Why This Matters

By defaulting to “People you Choose” for external sharing and “People in Perkins&Will” for internal collaboration, we reduce confusion, strengthen security, and keep access aligned with project needs and contractual obligations. The “Anyone” link is a tool—not a shortcut—to be used thoughtfully when standard access isn’t possible.

When in doubt, stop and check your sharing settings—or confirm with your Project Manager. A few extra seconds upfront can prevent access issues, rework, and unnecessary risk later on.

2026 Q1 Core eXchange Recap!

Core eXchange: Back to Basics and Building Shared Understanding

Last month’s Core eXchange presentation series focused on strengthening shared foundations across the firm. The sessions were intentionally designed as introductory and refresher content, creating space for teams to align around core tools, workflows, and ideas that support effective project delivery, digital practice, and sustainable design.

Returning to Fundamentals

A central theme of the series was expanding the “Back to Basics” approach from last October. Presentations revisited essential concepts such as early digital planning, right-sizing effort to project complexity, and establishing clear expectations at the start of work. These topics reinforced the importance of proactive decision-making and consistent setup as a way to reduce risk, improve efficiency, and support teams throughout the life of a project.

Shared Tools and Common Platforms

Another focus of the series was building familiarity and confidence with firmwide tools and platforms. Sessions emphasized how shared systems support people, projects, clients, and knowledge, and how small, regular interactions with these tools contribute to better visibility, coordination, and reporting. Rather than positioning these platforms as destinations, the series highlighted their role in supporting quick, everyday tasks that collectively strengthen firmwide insight and alignment.

Knowledge, Learning, and Accessibility

The series also reinforced the value of accessible knowledge and shared learning. Presentations showcased how guidance, research, and practical resources are organized to support teams in solving problems, exploring new approaches, and applying lessons learned across projects. By making expertise easier to find and apply, the series underscored how knowledge sharing supports consistency and continuous improvement.

Sustainability and Emerging Practices

Several sessions connected foundational workflows to broader environmental and design goals. Topics explored how materials, data, and decision-making intersect with sustainability, health, and long-term performance. These discussions positioned emerging practices not as isolated innovations, but as extensions of core design principles that can be integrated into everyday work.

Looking Ahead

Across all sessions, the consistent message was that strong digital and design practices are built on clarity, shared understanding, and intentional choices. By revisiting fundamentals and aligning around common approaches, Digital Practice and the Core eXchange lecture series continues to support teams in delivering high-quality, resilient, and forward-looking work.

All session recordings and slides are available in the Exchange Library on the Digital Practice site.

Thank you to all our Presenters!




View the Recordings on The Digital Practice Exchange Library

Back to Basics Series

Five Back to Basics sessions formed the foundation of this quarter’s program, each highlighting the essential workflows that aid with project delivery:

  • Back to Basics with Area Sync –Explained how to use Area Sync to track, validate, and reconcile program and design areas throughout a project lifecycle.  Click here for this session.

  • Back to Basics with Concept Analysis – Focused on using early-stage analysis to test design assumptions, evaluate options, and inform decision-making during schematic design. Click here for this session.

  • Back to Basics with CCA – Reviewed core CCA workflows and how consistent model checking, coordination, and issue tracking support quality, efficiency, and risk reduction. Click here for this session.

  • Back to Basics with Pull Planning – Covered collaborative pull planning methods to align teams around milestones, dependencies, and realistic project schedules early in the delivery process. Click here for this session.

  • Back to Basics: Teams and SharePoint – Demonstrated practical approaches for using Teams and SharePoint to organize files, manage communication, and maintain clear project documentation. Click here for this session.

Together, these sessions reinforced the importance of consistent, shared workflows and demonstrated how thoughtful use of core tools and processes supports clearer coordination, stronger decision-making, and more reliable project delivery.

excerpt.rendered: A look back and recap of the April 2025 Digital Practice Core eXchange.
